author: Peter Beaumont
title: Israel likely to pass bill retroactively legalising Jewish settlements | World news
text:
Israel’s parliament looks likely to approve a controversial bill to retroactively “legalise” illegal Jewish outposts built on privately owned Palestinian land, setting up inevitable confrontation with the international community.
As he prepared to fly back from meeting the UK prime minister in London, the Israeli leader, Benjamin Netanyahu , said on Monday he had informed the White House he was flying back to take part in the vote, indicating he would support its passage.
The legislation is scheduled to be voted on twice on Monday evening in the Knesset – despite threats that the law will be immediately challenged in the courts.

Commenting ahead of the vote, the UN envoy for the Middle East peace process, Nickolay Mladenov, said he was concerned by the bill as it would “enable the continued use of privately owned Palestinian land for Israeli settlements”.
“If adopted into law, it will have far-reaching legal consequences for Israel and greatly diminish the prospects for Arab-Israeli peace,” he added.
Netanyahu has blown hot and cold over the legislation – reportedly telling ministers he feared it would lead the country to the dock of the international criminal court. 
But Israeli media on Monday suggested Netanyahu intended to support the bill, which is opposed by Israel’s attorney general whose view is that the legislation is unconstitutional, but backed by rightwing ministers in Netanyahu’s coalition.
According to Netanyahu and reports in the Israeli media, the vote on the bill, which would essentially snatch private Palestinian land and give it to hardline settlers, was coordinated with the Trump administration .
A White House statement last week offered the mildest of criticism of a recent surge in Israeli settlement building announcements . It was read by some as expressing irritation that the Trump administration had not been forewarned of the Israeli plans ahead of a meeting between Trump and Netanyahu next Monday.

Speaking to Israeli reporters on Monday about the contacts with the White House, Netanyahu said: “That requires that we do not surprise our friends and keep them updated – and the American administration has been updated. This process was important for me, because we are trying to act this way, especially with very close friends. 
“I act responsibly and not according to different dictates and I will arrive [in Israel] tonight to vote on the law.”
Netanyahu has been under huge pressure from his far right over the legislation, particularly from the education minister, Naftali Bennett. The bill was introduced amid discussions over the high-profile demolition of the Amona illegal outpost that began last week and was completed on Monday.
The proposed legislation follows hard on the heels of the approval of some 6,000 new Jewish settlement housing units in the occupied Palestinian territories since Trump’s inauguration.
The issue of Israeli settlement building has been thrust into the foreground since the passage of a UN security council resolution in December , supported by the outgoing Obama administration, which condemned settlements as a “flagrant violation” of international law and an obstacle to peace.
Since Trump’s swearing-in, settler leaders and Bennett’s Jewish home party have been pushing Netanyahu, who is seen as weakened by a slew of police investigations , to push forward with building. Although the prime minister has chafed under the pressure he is largely dependent on Bennett to stay in office.
If adopted, the proposal would be seen as another step towards at least partial annexation of the West Bank, a key demand for parts of Netanyahu’s rightwing cabinet, including the hardline Jewish Home party.
The law is opposed, however, by some figures on the right including the hawkish defence minister, Avigdor Lieberman, who said last week: “The chance that it will be struck down by the supreme court is 100%.”
The bill’s defenders argue it will allow settlers to live without fear of being driven from their homes – many of which they have lived in for years. They accuse Israel’s justice system of being controlled by leftwing anti-settlement groups.
